transcript.text: Hi, my name is Von. I'm currently a
secondyear student at Swimbrand and I'm
undertaking a double degree of
engineering with law. And in
engineering, I am currently majoring or
at least hoping to major in megatronics.
So, this semester I embarked on a rather
interesting journey in one of my
engineering uh units. In this unit, I
basically worked in a team to research
uh rural indigenous communities across
Australia and to uh find problems they
were facing and create solutions uh
create innovative solutions using
emerging technologies. While researching
eventually my team and I settled on the
township of Arukun, which at the time or
at this time was facing water
contamination issues. As I mentioned
earlier, part of the research was
actually developing an innovative
solution which used emerging
technologies. And this is where I
designed this. So let's take a closer
look at this design. This is a 3D
printed component that can be attached
to plastic bottles and even jars via
solar distillation. So basically the way
this design works is that water from the
bottom container is evaporated by
sunlight and travels up through the
nozzle to the upper bottle where the
water is later condensed back into clean
and drinkable water. So as I mentioned
earlier, it's very important that this
design is 3D printed. And the point of
this is not only to satisfy the criteria
of having an emerging technology, but by
3D printing, I'm able to have a great
level of flexibility in the design,
making it more suitable for rural
communities to be able to modify these
designs. So, starting off, let's
actually look at the body itself.
Majority of the body is actually hollow
uh where there are large gaps within its
uh top surface. This was done
intentionally to reduce print time and
more importantly reduce material use.
You see, as printers take longer to
print, the probability of failures also
increase drastically where small errors
in calibration or print settings could
would more likely result in a failed
print. Another key feature that you
would have probably noticed looking at
this design is the connection points
that are available on the left and right
side. You might have already guessed,
but the point of this is so you can
actually connect multiple of these
designs together and be able to filter a
greater amount of water. The design is
also made in such a way that it can be
mounted using the mounting holes on the
side to solid walls or surfaces to
prevent it from tipping over while
filtering. The nozzle is also printed
separately to the body to allow the
users to select an appropriate nozzle
length depending on the bottle size. So
for instance, for larger bottles such as
2 L Coke cans, you will need a longer
nozzle whereas in smaller bottles you'll
require a shorter one. You might have
also noticed that the nozzle itself is
in the shape of a triangular prism
rather than a tube. This was done
because printing a triangular shape is
significantly easier than printing a
circular tube. This means that the
prints will be not only more affordable
but also more reliable as less
supporting structures will be required.
You might have also noticed that there's
a change in nozzle width across its
length. This was done to actually get
over the limitations regarding
tolerances within 3D printing. So when
fitting the nozzle together in this
design, instead of placing the nozzle on
top of the design through the cutouts,
you would actually press fit it from
underneath and later glue the uh the
gaps. This means that the design is
actually more reliable and more likely
to work even if different uh layer
heights are used during the print.
Overall, I believe that this project
provides a simple yet effective design
for providing access to clean water. In
conclusion, it was an absolute blast
working on this project as he has taught
me many valuable lessons that I've been
looking forward to using further down my
career. So, that's all from me. Thank
you for watching and I hope you've
learned something today. Take care and
have a good day.
